explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — This macro/inline must be inspected because it is invoked with '*token'. A macro expansion could contain side effects or assignments that modify the function parameter (or the object referred to by it). To prove the pointer parameter is not modified you must see the exact expansion/implementation.

OS_impl_filehandle_table — The table passed to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its type/definition can show whether the macro performs writes or takes addresses of its second argument that could lead to modification of the argument expression.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — The static call graph indicates this function is ultimately involved; inspect its signature/implementation because it may be invoked (directly or via the macro) with token-derived data and could modify the object or expect a non-const parameter. Understanding how it is called/used is necessary to ensure no parameter reassignment/side-effect occurs.

OS_object_token_t — The exact type definition (and whether it is an integer, struct, pointer alias, etc.) is required to determine what '*token' does and whether any use could modify the token pointer or the object it refers to.

OS_impl_file_internal_record_t — Needed to confirm the type of 'impl' and usage of its fields (impl->fd). While this does not directly affect pointer-parameter modification, inspecting how impl is obtained (via the table/macro) helps determine if intermediate operations modify the token parameter.

OS_SockAddr_t — Required to verify the types and qualifiers of AddrData and ActualLength and to ensure taking '&RemoteAddr->AddrData' and casting to 'const struct sockaddr *' does not result in any modification of the RemoteAddr pointer variable (or violate const-correctness in a way that implies modification).

sendto (prototype) — The called sendto implementation/signature must be known to ensure it does not take non-const pointers that could lead to the function passing pointer parameters in a way that causes modification of the pointer parameter (or to check if a wrapper exists that might modify arguments).

MSG_DONTWAIT — The flag macro is passed into sendto; include it to check for any unusual macro side-effects (rare, but necessary when auditing for parameter modification via macros).

OS_DEBUG — The debug macro is invoked when sendto fails; inspect its definition to ensure it does not rebind or otherwise modify any of the function parameters (or take their addresses and mutate them) as a side-effect.

Note: Standard library symbols like strerror and errno are not included because they do not affect whether the function reassigns its incoming pointer parameters. The above symbols are the ones that could plausibly contain expansions or implementations that reassign or otherwise modify the function parameters (pointer variables) or their referents.
